title: Biological Processing Centrifuges: Expert Insights
content:
Working Principle

The core working principle of a biological processing centrifuge is the use of centrifugal force. When the equipment is in operation, the rotor rotates at high speed, causing the biological samples placed in the rotor to be subjected to a strong centrifugal force. Due to differences in density, size, etc. among different components in the sample, they will settle at different speeds under the influence of centrifugal force, thereby achieving separation. For example, when processing blood samples, red blood cells, white blood cells, and plasma will be stratified due to different densities, facilitating subsequent extraction and analysis.

 

Applicable Fields

1. Pharmaceutical Industry: In the process of drug research and development and production, biological processing centrifuges can be used to separate and purify biological products such as antibiotics and vaccines, ensuring the purity and quality of drugs.

2. Bioengineering: It is often used in links such as cell collection after cell culture and protein purification, providing pure biological materials for bioengineering research.

3. Medical Field: It can separate and detect biological samples such as blood and urine, assisting in the diagnosis and treatment of diseases.

 

Operational Points

1. Sample Loading: Biological samples need to be evenly loaded into centrifuge tubes, and the weight of the centrifuge tubes must be balanced to avoid abnormal operation of the equipment or damage to samples due to imbalance.

2. Parameter Setting: Reasonably set parameters such as centrifugal speed, time, and temperature according to the characteristics of the sample and separation requirements. Different samples may require different centrifugal conditions. For example, for fragile cell samples, a lower centrifugal speed and appropriate temperature may be required.

3. Startup and Monitoring: After starting the equipment, closely monitor its operating status. If abnormal noise, vibration, or other situations are found, stop the equipment immediately and conduct an inspection.

 

Maintenance Methods

1. Daily Cleaning: After each use, clean the rotor, centrifugal chamber, and other components of the centrifuge to prevent sample residues from contaminating subsequent samples. Use appropriate cleaning agents during cleaning and avoid using highly corrosive chemicals.

2. Regular Inspection: Regularly inspect key components such as the motor and bearings of the equipment to check for wear, looseness, etc. At the same time, check whether the safety protection devices of the equipment, such as door locks and overspeed protection, are working properly.

3. Lubrication and Maintenance: According to the requirements of the equipment manual, regularly lubricate the parts that need lubrication to ensure the normal operation of the equipment and extend its service life.

 

Common Problems and Solutions

1. Poor Centrifugal Effect: It may be caused by improper setting of centrifugal parameters or unbalanced sample loading. The solution is to readjust the centrifugal parameters and ensure that the sample loading is balanced.

2. Abnormal Vibration of Equipment: Usually, it is because the centrifuge tube is unbalanced in weight or the rotor is improperly installed. In this case, stop the machine for inspection, adjust the weight distribution of the centrifuge tube, or reinstall the rotor.

3. Failure of Temperature Control: It may be a fault of the temperature sensor or a problem with the refrigeration/heating system. It is necessary to contact professional maintenance personnel for overhaul or replacement of relevant components.
section: Biological processing centrifuges are important equipment in fields such as bioengineering and pharmaceuticals. They achieve the separation and purification of biological samples through centrifugal force.
